great. thanks for the insight guys
even if you were to setup it to exactly replicate V3, you would still have better gas costs, better UX, and better risk management - tho you would be basically using 20% of its capabilities
as it can do everything that V3 does (better) and a lot more stuff
to be clear, from a purely technical perspective, Aave V4 is yes very different as it's reingeneered from the ground up, but functionally speaking it is an upgrade of V3 and a massive one at that

I mean the DAO made a decision to build (and paid also) for developing V4 as a continuation and to resolve certain challenges that existing infrastructure is not directly capable of addressing, and been following similar though process as the previous versions of migrations. If you take a look for example Aave V1 or V2, would be counter-intuitive to keep focusing on earlier version and their existing feature sets, but also there is another topic of upgradability that is addressed. Upgrading smart contract code that has $100B value is risky business, and something that LPs do see as risk vs immutable systems.

thanks for the insight

although if I read BGD Labs take correctly, "Aave v3.X and Aave v4 should be treated by the DAO as independent projects, not really understood as the continuation/replacement of the other, just different."

is it then a difference in take between BGD Labs // Avara (which would only show healthy dynamics inside the DAO) ?

I would be evolutionary, same has been for Aave V1, V2, V3 and now V4. Each version brings something new and optimization. But this still doesnâ€™t mean V3 is disappearing anytime soon as migrations will take time as we have seen with V2.

Not a hyperbole; itâ€™s just tiring to see such basic concepts misunderstood, misconstrued, and shared & generally accepted without question under the auspices that this was collaborated on by some big name actors.

They are conflating two unrelated concepts, â€œeconomic hard security limitâ€ and â€œcentralised stablecoin supplyâ€, into one when they have no meaningful relationship. The whole article is a hallucination on the premise that stable supply couldnâ€™t be higher than the cost of controlling ETH.
Hyperbole nice. Whatâ€™s the logical critique?
The biggest contagion risks are definitely related to a blocklisting of major defi venues
Yes, decentralised stables are extremely important but more so for their censorship resistance against their issuer than anything else
Overall this seems like a big AI hallucination that shouldnâ€™t pass any serious/honest review
And even those legal battles would be very quickly dismissed as all stablecoin providers have T&Cs regarding forks

On the contrary, the argument would be stronger that onchain collateralised stables pose a risk because they would be an extra honey pot for anyone controlling the fork. 

But even that is unlikely because social coordination would value this attacked chain at 0.
